events.title: Birth
events.summary: Heinrich Schütz was born in Köstritz as the eldest son of Christoph Schütz and Euphrosyne Bieger. His family moved to Weißenfels in 1590, where his father managed an inn.
events.fun_version: Heinrich Schütz was born in Köstritz as the eldest son of Christoph Schütz and Euphrosyne Bieger. His family moved to Weißenfels in 1590, where his father managed an inn!

events.title: Musical Discovery
events.summary: In 1598, during an overnight stay at his father's inn, Landgrave Moritz von Hessen-Kassel discovered Schütz's musical talents and requested to take him for further education.
events.fun_version: In 1598, during an overnight stay at his father's inn, Landgrave Moritz von Hessen-Kassel realized that Schutz could hit the right notes. So, naturally, he decided to take him under his wing to teach him the real art of making music instead!

events.title: Arrival at Landgrave's Court
events.summary: After much deliberation, Schütz's parents took him to the landgrave's court in Kassel in August 1599 for further musical instruction.
events.fun_version: After a lot of head-scratching and family meetings that probably felt like a never-ending episode of a soap opera, Schütz's parents decided to drop him off at the landgrave's musical boot camp in Kassel in August 1599. It’s like summer camp, but instead of s'mores, it’s all about scales and arpeggios!

events.title: Music Studies in Venice
events.summary: Schütz studied music with Giovanni Gabrieli in Venice from 1609 to 1612, marking a significant period in his musical education.
events.fun_version: So, picture this: Schütz, a guy with an ear for music, strutted his stuff to Venice from 1609 to 1612, learning under the legendary Giovanni Gabrieli. It’s like the ultimate music boot camp, if boot camps had gondolas and gelato!

events.title: Il primo libro de madrigali
events.summary: This marks Schütz's first major published work, a collection of madrigals. Published in Venice in 1611, it showcases his early style and contribution to music during this period.
events.fun_version: Imagine a time when people thought singing madrigals was the height of entertainment! Well, in 1611, Schutz decided to whip up his first major published work in Venice—a collection of madrigals showcasing his early style and contribution to music during this period.

events.title: Organist at Kassel
events.summary: He served as the organist at Kassel from 1613 to 1615, further establishing his career in music after his studies.
events.fun_version: He tickled the ivories as Kassel's organist from 1613 to 1615, proving that even back then, people knew how to make a career out of going 'chopsticks!' His time there further established his career in music after his studies.

events.title: Move to Dresden
events.summary: After a prolonged negotiation between the landgrave and the elector, Schütz moved to Dresden to work as court composer to the Elector of Saxony.
events.fun_version: After enduring negotiations that might have broken records, Schütz relocated to Dresden to fulfill his new role as court composer for the Elector of Saxony. He was eager to make music, but secretly hoped they wouldn’t ask him to showcase any interpretive dance moves along the way!

events.title: Marriage to Magdalena Wildeck
events.summary: In 1619 Schütz married Magdalena Wildeck, who bore two daughters before her death in 1625.
events.fun_version: Schütz married Magdalena Wildeck in 1619, and they had two daughters. Sadly, she passed away in 1625.

events.title: Psalmen Davids (Book 1)
events.summary: Published in Dresden in 1619, this collection of psalms reflects Schütz's deepening exploration of sacred music, further establishing his reputation in the genre.
events.fun_version: In 1619, Schütz published a collection of psalms in Dresden, reflecting his deepening exploration of sacred music. Apparently, he thought it might just be the secret to getting more divine fan mail, further establishing his reputation in the genre.

events.title: Birth of Anna Justina
events.summary: Anna Justina was born in 1621, one of the daughters of Schütz and Magdalena Wildeck.
events.fun_version: Anna Justina popped into this world in 1621, clearly on a holiday from the boring life of being just another little daughter of her folks, Schütz and Magdalena Wildeck. You could say she didn’t just step out of the womb; she bounced out like a rubber ball at a Renaissance fair, destined to leave a mark—or at least a funny story!

events.title: Birth of Euphrosyne
events.summary: Euphrosyne was born in 1623, another daughter of Schütz and Magdalena Wildeck.
events.fun_version: Euphrosyne burst onto the scene in 1623 like an unexpected guest at a medieval dinner party—turns out, she was just another addition to the grand feast prepared by Schütz and Magdalena Wildeck!

events.title: Historia der ... Aufferstehung ...
events.summary: This work, published in 1623 in Dresden, is notable for its religious theme and showcases Schütz's compositional skills in the context of sacred music.
events.fun_version: Back in 1623, in the fancy city of Dresden, someone thought it was a good idea to mix divine inspiration with a little bit of music making. This notable work, which could have powered a heavenly karaoke machine, showcases Schütz’s impressive compositional skills in the context of sacred music—because nothing says ‘holy’ like a symphony that might just make the angels tap their feet!

events.title: Cantiones sacrae
events.summary: Published in Freiberg in 1625, this collection of sacred songs highlights Schütz's innovative approaches to vocal music, further enhancing his legacy in choral works.
events.fun_version: Published in Freiberg in 1625, this collection of sacred songs is so sacred that even the composers in heaven are tuning in! Schütz's innovative approaches to vocal music enhance his legacy in choral works, making angels stop their harps to listen!

events.title: Becker Psalter
events.summary: This version was published in Freiberg in 1628, revised in 1661, and emphasizes Schütz's role in incorporating these hymns into musical practice.
events.fun_version: This version was published in Freiberg in 1628, and just like a good wine, it got a makeover in 1661! It's like Schutz was on a mission to make these hymns sound so good that even the angels were tapping their feet!

events.title: Visit to Venice
events.summary: In 1628 he went to Venice again, where he may have met Claudio Monteverdi.
events.fun_version: In 1628, he decided to visit Venice again—because, clearly, he couldn't resist the idea of getting lost in all those canals. I mean, who doesn’t want to bump into the great Claudio Monteverdi while dodging a few gondolas?

events.title: Symphoniae sacrae (Book 1)
events.summary: This notable work, released in Venice in 1629, is part of a series that combines innovative harmonies with sacred texts, showcasing Schütz's unique style.
events.fun_version: In 1629, Schütz released a notable work in Venice as part of a series, creating unique harmonies by mixing sacred texts and innovative sounds, resulting in something divine!

events.title: Invitation to Copenhagen
events.summary: In 1633 he was invited to Copenhagen to compose the music for wedding festivities there, before returning to Dresden in 1635.
events.fun_version: In 1633, our hero was invited to Copenhagen to compose the music for wedding festivities. After this musical adventure – and likely a few pieces of cake – he made a swift exit back to peaceful Dresden in 1635!

events.title: Kleine geistliche Konzerte (Book 1)
events.summary: Published in Leipzig in 1636, this collection contains smaller sacred concerts, marking a significant contribution to the German choral tradition.
events.fun_version: So, picture this: back in 1636, in the hip city of Leipzig, a bunch of sacred concerts were published. It’s like the Spotify of the 17th century for church music! It’s a big deal, especially if you’re into German choral vibes. This collection marks a significant contribution to the German choral tradition.

events.title: Musikalische Exequien
events.summary: Schütz's funeral music for his noble friend Heinrich Posthumus of Reuss is considered a masterpiece and is known today as the first German Requiem. This work showcases Schütz's ability to convey deep emotion through his compositions, illustrating his sensitivity to the text and its meaning.
events.fun_version: Schütz's funeral music for his buddy Heinrich Posthumus of Reuss is a masterpiece and the first German Requiem on record! If emotions had a concert, this would be the headliner, showcasing Schütz's deep feels and his sensibility to the text like a poetic maestro.

events.title: Kleine geistliche Konzerte (Book 2)
events.summary: The second volume of sacred concerts was also published in Leipzig, in 1639, continuing Schütz's exploration of shorter sacred works.
events.fun_version: In 1639, Leipzig decided to throw a party for sacred music writers! They brought out the second volume of sacred concerts, continuing Schütz's exploration of shorter sacred works, probably thinking, 'Why not make shorter works so people can get back to their day jobs?' I mean, who doesn't love a sacred music quickie?

events.title: Extended Visit to Denmark
events.summary: He conducted an extended visit to Denmark in 1641, due to the devastation of the Electoral court.
events.fun_version: He conducted an extended visit to Denmark in 1641 due to the devastation caused by the Electoral court's unfortunate circumstances, which seemed like a party that everyone wanted to avoid.

events.title: Symphoniae sacrae (Book 2)
events.summary: This work was released in Dresden in 1647, further solidifying Schütz's impact on Baroque sacred music with its intricate choral arrangements.
events.fun_version: In 1647, the ever-so-serious Dresden found itself caught in a musical revolution when Schutz unleashed his magnificent choral arrangements upon it. The choirs were so intricate that even they were confused—was that a note or a sneeze? Baroque music was never the same!

events.title: End of the Thirty Years' War
events.summary: The Thirty Years' War ended in 1648, allowing Schütz to become more active in Dresden.
events.fun_version: After the fiery Thirty Years' War, which can be likened to a never-ending family argument but with more swords, we finally hit 1648! With the dust finally settling, Schütz could step out and say, ‘Okay, who's ready for some music in Dresden now that we're not killing each other anymore?’

events.title: Geistliche Chor-Music
events.summary: This influential choral music collection was published in Dresden in 1648, showcasing Schütz's mastery in writing for choir and continuing his religious contributions.
events.fun_version: In 1648, some folks in Dresden published an influential choral music collection that showcased Schütz's mastery in writing for choir, continuing his significant religious contributions while transforming a mere gathering into an experience filled with musical harmony!

events.title: Symphoniae sacrae (Book 3)
events.summary: Published in 1650 in Dresden, this third book continues the legacy of Schütz's symphonic choral works, enriched with a variety of styles and forms.
events.fun_version: The third book, published in 1650 in Dresden, continues the legacy of Schütz's symphonic choral works, enriched with a variety of styles and forms, packing in a buffet of styles and forms that even a symphony conductor would envy!

events.title: Post as Kapellmeister at Wolfenbüttel
events.summary: In 1655, the year his daughter Euphrosyne died, he accepted an ex officio post as Kapellmeister at Wolfenbüttel.
events.fun_version: In 1655, the year his daughter Euphrosyne died, he thought, 'Why not throw in the towel and accept the fancy title of Kapellmeister at Wolfenbüttel?' Because who wouldn't want to conduct a little music?

events.title: Zwölf geistliche Gesänge
events.summary: This collection, released in Dresden in 1657, features twelve sacred songs that exhibit Schütz's enduring dedication to sacred music.
events.fun_version: So, back in the glorious year of 1657—when the wigs were big and music was sacred—a bunch of twelve holy tunes hit the stage in Dresden! Our buddy Schütz was so committed to sacred music that he probably wore a halo while composing! This collection truly showcases his enduring dedication.

events.title: Historia der ... Geburt ... Jesu Christi
events.summary: Published in 1664, this Christmas Story from Dresden exemplifies Schütz's ability to convey religious narratives through music.
events.fun_version: Back in 1664, a composer named Schütz decided to drop a Christmas Story from Dresden, which beautifully exemplifies his knack for conveying religious narratives through music. He thought, 'Why not turn this holiday tale into a musical blockbuster?' And just like that, he made sure to sprinkle some divine vibes along with the jingle bells!

events.title: Lukas-Passion
events.summary: This significant work, written in 1665 in Dresden, represents Schütz's contribution to the Passion oratorio tradition, focusing on the passion of Christ according to St. Luke.
events.fun_version: Back in 1665, in the not-so-glitzy city of Dresden, a genius named Schütz made a significant contribution to the Passion oratorio tradition. He thought to himself, 'Why not create a piece focusing on the passion of Christ according to St. Luke?' It's like writing a hit song about your ex – definitely emotional!

events.title: Johannes-Passion
events.summary: Released in 1666 in Dresden, this Passion setting is an important aspect of Schütz's output, emphasizing the events of Christ's passion according to St. John.
events.fun_version: In 1666, Dresden dropped a musical bomb—Schütz's Passion setting! This masterpiece is like the original scrolling story of what happened to Christ, but told with a way better soundtrack, according to St. John.

events.title: Matthäus-Passion
events.summary: Also completed in 1666 in Dresden, this work is a notable setting of the Passion according to St. Matthew, showcasing Schütz's dramatic flair.
events.fun_version: Completed in 1666 in Dresden, this notable work is not just a musical setting of the Passion according to St. Matthew; it’s Schütz showing off his dramatic flair like he’s auditioning for a role in a baroque soap opera!

events.title: Königs und Propheten 119er Psalm ...
events.summary: Published in 1671 in Dresden, this final opus includes various pieces, solidifying Schütz's legacy as one of the key figures in early Baroque music.
events.fun_version: Published in 1671 in Dresden, this final opus includes various pieces, solidifying Schütz's legacy as one of the key figures in early Baroque music. It's like the early Baroque equivalent of dropping the mic after an epic performance!

events.title: Later Life
events.summary: In his later years, Heinrich Schütz returned to Weißenfels where he lived with his sister in a house that has become a museum dedicated to his life. Despite his retirement, he was frequently summoned back to Dresden by the Electoral Court. Schütz passed away in Dresden due to a stroke in 1672 and his burial site at the old Frauenkirche was lost when the church was demolished in 1727.
events.fun_version: Heinrich Schütz, the rock star of baroque music, decided to retire and move back to Weißenfels, sharing a cozy house with his sister where a museum dedicated to his life now resides. Even in retirement, he was frequently called back to Dresden by the Electoral Court — they couldn't get enough of him! Sadly, he left this earthly stage due to a stroke in 1672, and his burial site was lost when the Frauenkirche was demolished in 1727.
